title-group.article-title: Isolation and evaluation of virucidal activities of flavanone glycosides and rosmarinic acid derivatives from Dracocephalum spp. against feline calicivirus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Isolation and evaluation of virucidal activities of flavanone glycosides and rosmarinic acid derivatives from
Dracocephalum spp.
against feline calicivirus

sec.title: Orphanage

, Erdenechimeg Selenge c , Yohei Takeda d , Javzan Batkhuu e , Haruko Ogawa f , Dulamjav Jamsransuren f , Keisuke Suganuma d, g , Toshihiro Murata h, *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Virucidal activity
Feline calicivirus
Flavanone glycoside
Stilbenoid glycoside
Rosmarinic acid
ABSTRACT

Feline calicivirus is one of the surrogate viruses of human norovirus. This study aimed to identify virucidal compounds, chemical constituents of plants from the genus
Dracocephalum
, which are rich in flavonoids and phenylpropanoid oligomers. Four undescribed compounds, including a flavanone glucoside, two stilbenoid glycosides, and a phenylpropanoid amide glycoside, as well as 17 known compounds, were isolated from the Mongolian plants
Dracocephalum fruticulosum Stephan ex Willd.
, and
D. nutans
L. belonging to the family Lamiaceae . The structures of the compounds were determined based on NMR, MS, and electronic CD spectroscopic data. In addition to these 21 compounds, 15 previously reported compounds from
D. foetidum Bunge
in C.F. von Ledebour were included, and a total of 36 compounds were evaluated for their virucidal activities against feline calicivirus. Some of the flavanone glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers showed virucidal activities, and their structural features are discussed. The findings suggest that isosakuranetin glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers may have the potential for norovirus inactivation.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In this study, we focused on Mongolian plants of the genus
Dracocephalum
as potential sources of candidate antiviral compounds.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure elucidation
sec.p: The ECD spectrum of 5 was close to that of 1 , which indicated that C-2 of 5 was also in the ( S )-absolute configuration.

The molecular formula of 20 was assigned to be C 27 H 34 O 15 based on HRFABMS data (positive): m / z 599.1982 [M+H] + (calcd for C 27 H 35 O 15 : 599.1976), including one more oxygen atom than in 19 . In the 1 H NMR spectrum of 20 (methanol- d 4 , Table 1 ), the o - and/or m -coupling pattern protons ( δH 6.72, 1H, d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-2; 7.16, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, H-5; 6.62, 1H, d, J = 8.0, 2.0 Hz H-6) showed the presence of an m , p - dioxygenated benzene ring moiety. The hydroxy proton resonance at δH 7.85 was observed in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 20 (DMSO‑ d 6 , Table 1 ), suggesting the presence of an additional hydroxy group compared to 19 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra were similar to those of 19 , except for the presence of an m , p -dioxygenated benzene ring instead of the p -oxygenated benzene ring of 19 . These MS and NMR data suggested that the aglycone of 20 was a 4- O -3,13-dihydroxy-14-carboxydihydrostylbenoid moiety ( Fig. 4 ). In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 4 ), H-Glc-II-1 ( δH 4.74, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz) was long-range coupled with C-Glc-2 ( δC 83.5), and H-Glc-1 ( δH 4.72, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz) was coupled with C-4 ( δC 145.2). These correlations showed the presence of a 4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O - β- D-glucopyranosyl moiety. The nuclear Overhauser effect correlation between H-Glc-1 and H-5 ( δH 7.16, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz) supported the bonding of the glucosyl moiety to C-4 ( Fig. 4 ). Therefore, 20 was determined to be 2-{2-[3-hydroxy-4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O - β- D-glucopyranosyl-phenyl]ethyl}-6-hydroxybenzoic acid, as shown in Fig. 1 .
a In methanol- d solution.
4 b In DMSO‑ d solution.
6 c Unclear signal pattern due to overlapping.

sec.title: 2.2. Virucidal activities
sec.p:
FCV-inactivating activities of the compounds derived from
D. fruticulosum
,
D . nutans
, and
D . foetidum
( 1–36 ) were evaluated. Among the 10
D. fruticulosum
-derived compounds ( 1–4 , 8 , 9 , 15–18 ), treatment with 1 , 2 , 3 , 15 , 16 , and 17 resulted in lower viral titers than that in the dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) group after 48 h of incubation, which indicated that these compounds had virucidal activity ( Fig. 5A ). Moreover, 1 , 2 , and 17 showed virucidal activities after 6 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group, which was the value of Y-axis [log 10 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID 50 )/ml] in the DMSO group minus that value in each test compound group, was 1.63, 1.25, and 1.80 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 1 , 2 , and 17 , respectively. The virucidal activities of these three compounds seemed to be comparable ( Fig. 5B ). On the other hand, the viral titers in groups 4 , 8 , 9 , and 18 were comparable to those in the DMSO group after 48 h of incubation, which indicated that these compounds did not have virucidal activity ( Fig. S2A ). Among the 12
D. nutans
-derived compounds ( 5–7 , 10–15 , and 19–21 ), 5 , 7 , and 15 showed virucidal activities after 48 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group was 1.13, 1.30, and ≥2.17 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 5 , 7 , and 15 , respectively ( Fig. 5C ). However, these compounds did not show virucidal activity after 6 h of incubation ( Fig. 5D ), whereas 6 , 10–14 , and 19–21 showed no virucidal activity even after 48 h of incubation ( Fig. S2B ). Among the 15
D. foetidum
-derived compounds, 22 and 25 showed virucidal activities after 48 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group was ≥1.83 and ≥2.17 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 22 and 25 , respectively ( Fig. 5E ). However, these compounds did not show virucidal activity after 6 h of incubation ( Fig. 5F ), whereas 23 , 24 , and 26–36 showed no virucidal activity even after 48 h of incubation ( Fig. S2C ).

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
An undescribed isosakuranetin glucoside was isolated from
D. fruticulosum
. Furthermore, undescribed compounds, including two stilbene glycosides and a phenylpropanoid amide glycoside, were obtained from
D. nutans
. Virucidal activities against FCV, a surrogate viruses of human norovirus, were evaluated for a total of 36 compounds, including flavonoids, flavonoid glycosides, phenylpropanoids, phenylpropanoid glycosides, a benzyl glucoside, and monoterpene glycosides, from three
Dracocephalum spp.
plants. Among these compounds, isosakuranetin and naringenin glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers, including rosmarinic acid, schizotenuin A, and lycopic acid A, showed virucidal activities. These results suggested the potential for the flavanone glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers to be used for norovirus inactivation.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were recorded on a P-2300 polarimeter (JASCO Corp., Tokyo, Japan ). UV spectra were recorded on an MPS-2450 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Kyoto , Japan ). ECD spectra were recorded on a J-700 spectropolarimeter (JASCO). 1 H NMR (400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (100 MHz), 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC (optimized for 1 J C-H = 145 Hz), and HMBC (optimized for n J C-H = 8 Hz) spectra were recorded on a JNM-AL400 FT-NMR spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ), HOHAHA spectra were recorded on a JNM-LAMBDA400 FT-NMR spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ), NOE spectra were recorded using a JEOL JNM-EX270 FT-NMR spectrometer, and chemical shifts are provided as δ values with TMS as an internal standard. HRFABMS data were obtained on a JMS700 mass spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd.) using either m -nitrobenzyl alcohol or a glycerol matrix. A porous polymer gel (Diaion HP-20; Mitsubishi Chemical Co., Tokyo , Japan ) was used for column chromatography. Preparative HPLC was performed on a JASCO 2089 instrument (columns: TSKgel ODS-120T, 21.5 × 300 mm , Tosoh, Tokyo , Japan ; Cosmosil AR-II, 20 × 250 mm , Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto , Japan ; Cosmosil 5 PE-MS, 20 × 250 mm , Nacalai Tesque; Develosil C 30 -UG-5, 20 × 250 mm , Nomura Chemical Aichi , Japan ; Mightysil RP-18 GP, 10 × 250 mm , Kanto Chemical Co., Inc., Tokyo , Japan ) with UV detection at 210 nm .

sec.title: 4.2. Plant materials
sec.p:
Aerial parts of
Dracocephalum fruticulosum Steph. ex Willd. (Lamiaceae)
were collected in
July 2006
in Mongolia (
46 ◦ 02.256 ′ N
;
102 ◦ 20.527 ′ E
)
.
Prof. Ch. Sanchir from the Institute of Botany , Mongolian Academy of Sciences , identified the plant species. A voucher specimen (N◦ 90.7.5.06B) was deposited at the herbarium of the Laboratory of Bioorganic Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, National University of Mongolia
.

Aerial parts of
Dracocephalum nutans
L. ( Lamiaceae ) were collected in
July 2010
in Mongolia (
49 ◦ 58.23 ′ N
;
92 ◦ 02.809 ′ E
)
.
Prof. Ch. Sanchir from the Institute of Botany , Mongolian Academy of Sciences , identified the plant species. A voucher specimen (N◦ 90.7.11.16A) was deposited at the herbarium of the Laboratory of Bioorganic Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, National University of Mongolia
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
Dried aerial parts of
D. fruticulosum
( 40 g ) were extracted with acetone/H 2 O (4:1) (1L × 2) at room temperature for a total of 4 weeks. The crude extract ( 7.24 g ) was obtained after concentration, and the extract residue was dissolved in H 2 O; the aqueous solution was subjected to chromatography on a porous polymer gel (Diaion HP- 20, 200 g ) and eluted with H 2 O (fraction 1A, 3.99 g ), MeOH/H 2 O (1:1) (fraction 1B, 1.18 g ), and MeOH (fraction 1C, 1.22 g ). Fraction 1B was subjected to chromatography on an ODS-SM-50C-M column (Yamazen Co., Osaka , Japan ) and eluted with 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O to obtain compounds 8 (8.0 mg), 9 ( 18.5 mg ), and 15 ( 51.1 mg ). Fraction 1C was subjected to chromatography on an ODS-SM-50C-M column and eluted with 50% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 2A–2L). Fraction 2C (58.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)] to yield compound 2 ( 15.9 mg ). Fraction 2D ( 185.8 mg ) was subjected to HPLC (AR-II column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA; 5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compounds 15 ( 45.6 mg ), 17 ( 5.5 mg ), and 18 ( 2.8 mg ). Fraction 2H ( 70.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 30–35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 3 . Fraction 2I ( 97.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA; Mightysil RP-18 column; mobile phase: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 1 ( 4.6 mg ), 4 ( 39.8 mg ), and 16 ( 3.8 mg ).

Dried aerial parts of
D. nutans
( 50 g ) were extracted with acetone/ H 2 O (4:1) (1L × 2) at room temperature for a total of 7 weeks. The crude extract ( 7.83 g ) was obtained after concentration, and the extract residue was dissolved in H 2 O; the aqueous solution was subjected to chromatography on a porous polymer gel (Diaion HP- 20, 200 g ) and eluted with H 2 O (fraction 3A, 3.91 g ), MeOH/H 2 O (1:1) (fraction 3B, 1.09 g ), and MeOH (fraction 3C, 1.46 g ). Fraction 3B was subjected to chromatography on an ODS column (TSK-gel, ODS-120T) and eluted with 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 4A–4O). Fractions 4C and 4D ( 169.8 mg ) were subjected to HPLC (Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compound 12 ( 66.4 mg ). Fractions 4E–4G ( 193.3 mg ) were subjected to HPLC (Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compounds 5 ( 6.3 mg ) and 15 ( 32.7 mg ). Fractions 4I and 4J (25.0 mg) were subjected to HPLC [Mightysil RP-18 column; mobile phase: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 19 ( 2.7 mg ) and 20 ( 2.3 mg ). Fraction 3C was subjected to chromatography on an ODS column (TSK-gel, ODS-120T) and eluted with 20%–30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 5A-5M). Fraction 5C ( 55.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield 15 ( 17.6 mg ). Fraction 5D ( 55.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 14 ( 7.3 mg ) and 19 ( 2.5 mg ). Fraction 5E ( 31.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phases: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 20 (3.0 mg). Fraction 5F (35.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 10 (10.0 mg). Fraction 5H (126.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 , column; mobile phases: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 7 ( 9.7 mg ) and 13 ( 4.4 mg ). Fraction 5J ( 84.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phases: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 6 ( 21.2 mg ). Fraction 5K ( 50.6 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 11 ( 6.1 mg ) and 21 (9.0 mg).

(2 S )-Isosakuranetin 7- O -β- D-(6 ′′ - O -malonyl)glucopyranoside ( 1 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 535.1455 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 25 H 27 O 13 : 535.1451). [α] 26 D 38.5 ( c 0.40, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max 284, 324; ECD ( c 0.0002, MeOH) nm ([ θ ]) 215 (26400), 234 (600), 248 (8500), 286 (26100), 333 (7000) nm; 1 H-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz and DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz), Table 1 .

2-Hydroxy-6-{2-[4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O -β- D-glucopyranosylphenyl]ethyl}benzoic acid ( 19 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 583.2028 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 27 H 35 O 14 : 583.2027). [α] 25 D 19.3 ( c 0.27, MeOH); 1 H-NMR: (DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (DMSO‑ d 6 , 100 MHz), Table 1 .

2-{2-[3-Hydroxy-4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl-phenyl]ethyl}-6-hydroxybenzoic acid ( 20 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 599.1982 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 27 H 35 O 15 : 599.1976). [α] 25 D 11.3 ( c 0.32, MeOH); 1 H-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz and DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz), Table 1 .

sec.title: 4.4. Acid hydrolysis and sugar identification
sec.p:
Compounds 1 ( 0.5 mg ), 19 (1.0 mg), 20 ( 0.9 mg ), and 21 ( 1.8 mg ) were hydrolyzed with 3.5 N HCl (0.5 ml) at 60 ◦ C for 3 h. The reaction mixtures were subjected to chromatography on an HP-20 resin column (5 × 50 mm ), and water eluates (5 ml) were concentrated. Each residue was stirred with L-cysteine methyl ester (2, 3, 2, and 2 mg , respectively) and O -tolyl isothiocyanate (5 μl) in pyridine (0.5 ml), using a previously reported procedure (
).

The reaction mixtures were analyzed by HPLC [J-Pak Symphonia C18 column, 4.6 × 250 nm ; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA at 1.0 ml/min; detection at 250 nm ]. D-Glucose ( t R = 27.1 min) in 1 , 19 , 20 , and 21 and L-rhamnose ( t R = 46.2 min) in 21 were identified as their glycosidic moieties, based on comparisons with authentic samples of a D-glucose derivative ( t R = 27.1 min), an L-glucose derivative ( t R = 24.6 min), and an L-rhamnose derivative ( t R = 46.2 min).

sec.title: 4.5. Evaluation of FCV-inactivating activity
4.6. Statistical analysis
sec.p: The student’ s t -test was performed to analyze the statistical significance of the difference in viral titer between each test compound group and the DMSO group. P values < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We thank Mr. S. Sato, and Mr. T. Matsuki of Tohoku Pharmaceutical University, for assisting with the MS measurements. We also thank Sachiko Matsuda of Obihiro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine for her technical assistance. We are grateful to Dr. K. Maeda ( Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi , Japan ) for providing FCV (F9 strain) and CRFK cells. We are grateful to Dr. F. Yoshizaki and Dr. K. Sasaki, for providing us with valuable advice. This work was supported by a grant from JSPS Kakenhi (grant number 21H02638, 19 K16397 ). This work was partially supported by an Advanced Research Grant from the National University of Mongolia, the Kanno Foundation of Japan , the Cooperative Research Grant (31-joint-5) of National Research Center for Protozoan Diseases, Obihiro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine, and JST/JICA SATREPS (JPMJSA1906). We would like to thank Editage (www.editage.com) for English language editing.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112896.
